answer.value: In this tool, you’ll explore the frequency of alleles and genotypes in a population using a simulator based on a mathematical model. Use the simulator to explore your own questions about how allele and genotype frequencies are affected by natural selection, migration, mutation, and more.
Additional information can be found on this resource’s webpage
This resource contains the following sections in the top and bottom menus:

value: The “Introduction” tab (top) provides a brief overview of population genetics and the model.
The “Simulations” tabs (top) are where you can access the model simulator. Navigate the simulator by following the instructions in each section.
The “Model Background” page (bottom) provides more information about the biological concepts and terms used in the model.
The “Help” page (bottom) provides more support for using the simulator.

answer.value: Throughout the resource, you can select bold underlined text and question mark icons to show additional information and links.
For more information on using this resource, refer to the materials on this resource’s webpage
This resource is optimized for use on computers and mobile devices. It is supported by the most recent versions of Google Chrome, Firefox, Microsoft Edge, and Safari web browsers
This resource has been designed, optimized, and tested for accessibility compliance (WCAG Level 2.1 AA Success Criteria).
Submit comments, questions, or feedback about this resource via email to biointeractive@hhmi.org.

question: References
answer: John R. Shaffer and Joshua Rogan. “Online human population genetics simulator: a tool for genetics/genomics education and research.”(poster, American Society of Human Genetics 65th Annual Meeting.Baltimore, MD, Oct. 9, 2015).
